info.game_comments:
2012 Power Players Week game 5.
From DAR Constitution Hall in Washington, D.C.

(1, 1).clue: Central Alabama's Black Belt is famous for growing this fiber that was once "king"

(4, 1).clue: The documentary "Client 9" chronicled "The Rise and Fall of" this New York governor

(1, 2).clue: As part of their uniforms, beginners in judo & karate first wear belts of this color

(4, 2).clue: The initial claim about his affair with Sally Hemings was printed in a Richmond newspaper

(5, 2).clue: "Warm" rhyming term for a place with a strong WiFi connection

(1, 3).clue: In the late 1950s Nils Bohlin of this Swedish company pioneered the use of safety belts in automobiles

(3, 3).clue: No more tears for this company, JNJ

(4, 3).clue: Lady Emma Hamilton was this British naval hero's mistress & inherited money from him after he died at Trafalgar

(5, 3).clue: in 2011 Business Week said European government bonds were this "poisonous" kind of debt

(1, 4).clue: These objects also known as planetoids are mainly found in a "belt" of them between the orbits of Mars & Jupiter

(3, 4).clue: This company providing energy products & services is HAL

(4, 4).clue: Sydney Biddle Barrows, who had a high-class pedigree & ran a high-class sex service, was dubbed this

(5, 4).clue: It's the "tiny" term for a person who writes short posts about one's personal life on Tumblr or Twitter

(1, 5).clue: Albrecht Classen's "The Medieval" this belt designed to protect a woman's virtue concludes they were never really in use

(3, 5).clue: BUD is for you, as it's the symbol for this hyphenated pair of names

(4, 5).clue: In 1745 Louis XV took her as his official mistress; she gave her name to a fabric & a big hairstyle

(5, 5).clue: In March 2009 Pres. Obama told "60 Minutes" that the U.S. needed one of these 2-word plans for leaving Afghanistan

(1, 1).clue: Here's a mystery: she wrote romantic novels under the pseudonym Mary Westmacott

(3, 1).clue: Bonanza, Idaho is now this abandoned type of "town" that faded away after the gold was gone

(4, 1).clue: 1994:"A cop versus a mad bomber who's rigged a bomb to a bus"

(5, 1).clue: Condemning the overthrow of the Queen, I withdrew the treaty to annex these islands, now a state

(6, 1).clue: In a Police song about a castaway, Sting approved a "Message In" one of these

(1, 2).clue: This sci-fi author made his "Final Odyssey" in 2008, dying at age 90

(3, 2).clue: Rising in our nation's Capital just a few blocks from here, it was once known as Jenkins Hill

(4, 2).clue: 2010:"Docudrama about the Triple Crown-winning race horse"

(5, 2).clue: In 1894 I became the first president to be protected by these men from the Treasury Department

(6, 2).clue: On a BBS, short for this "system", your online moderator approves of all messages that follow the rules

(1, 3).clue: He also produced stationary sculptures called stabiles

(3, 3).clue: On Feb. 3, 1947 a village in this territory bordering Alaska recorded -81.4 F., an all-time low for Canada

(4, 3).clue: 1953:"Life on a Honolulu Army post just before the Pearl Harbor attack"

(6, 3).clue: Eugene H. Peterson approved "The Message", a contemporary version of this, with all 66 books combined into one

(1, 4).clue: Awarded a Nobel Prize, this existentialist said he would have given it to fellow Frenchman Andre Malraux

(3, 4).clue: Fodor's says that Paris is no longer deserted in this month as was traditionally the case

(5, 4).clue: I sent troops in to quell the 1894 Pullman Railroad strike because it was interrupting the delivery of this

(6, 4).clue: The Pope approved his message for this holiday in 2012; it said, "May the risen Christ grant hope to the Middle East"

(1, 5).clue: This British journalist was masterful as the longtime host of "Masterpiece Theatre"

(3, 5).clue: The iconic flag raising on Iwo Jima in 1945 took place on this hill (okay, "mount")

(4, 5).clue: 1969:"Sam Peckinpah's tale of aging gunmen in 1913 Texas"

(5, 5).clue: In 1863 I paid George Benninsky $150 to do this instead of me; it was perfectly legal, & George didn't get killed

(6, 5).clue: Marshall McLuhan would approve if you said this "is the message"; it's his most famous quote

(0, 0).clue: The National Inventors Hall of Fame said his work "brought the South prosperity", but he was out of business within 5 years
